datafield.subfield: Seven Stories, the National Centre for Children's Books
Over the hills and far away, 2015:
title page (Elizabeth Hammill) back flap (Elizabeth Hammill is a critic and bookseller, as well as cofounder of Seven Stories, Britain's National Centre for Children's Books)

Elizabeth Hammill's labour of love finally makes the book shops, 7 October 2014 (Elizabeth Hammill, born in America but resident for many years in Jesmond, Elizabeth was awarded an honorary doctorate by Newcastle University in 2006 and an honorary OBE the following year; a social work intern in Harlem when she was a student in the 1960s; moved to Britain with her parents, met her husband and moved to New York where she taught dyslexic children; returned to Britain and was on the parents' committee at West Jesmond Primary School where she started up a school bookshop; helped to organize the first Northern Children's Book Festival and set up a literary magazine for teenagers by teenagers; with Jay Maudslay, Newcastle City Council's chief education advisor whowas killed in Thailand when a hotel collapsed, and then with Mary Briggs, Elizabeth set in train the sequence of events that would lead to the opening in 2005 of Seven Stories.)

(Elizabeth Hammill; Seven Stories was founded as a charity in 1996 by Elizabeth Hammill and Mary Briggs. They recognized Britain needed an institution whose mission was to collect, champion and celebrate its children's literature; national status was awarded at the end of 2012, National Center for Children's Books.)

(Elizabeth Hammill was a primary teacher in New York City, a book-loving mother of two sons, and a nationally recognized children's bookseller in Newcastle upon Tyne; lectured at Newcastle University; edited a unique literary magazine In brief : by teenagers for teenagers (1989-1998) and has reviewed and written features for many of the top children's literature journals in the UK; was awarded an honorary Doctorate by Newcastle University in 2006, an honorary OBE in 2007, and an Alumnae Achievement Award by her American alma mater Mount Holyoke College in 2009 for her services to children's literature; she and her husband live in Newcastle upon Tyne.)
